description:
Vairimorpha necatrix is a species of microsporidian, a group of obligate intracellular parasites that infect a wide range of invertebrate hosts, including insects. Microsporidians are classified as fungi, but they exhibit unique characteristics that set them apart from other fungal groups.

Vairimorpha necatrix is a pathogen of the caterpillars of the gypsy moth, Lymantria dispar, a major forest pest. The life cycle of V. necatrix involves the production of resistant spores that can infect the caterpillar host. Once inside the host, the spores germinate and release infective sporoplasms, which then replicate within the host's cells, leading to the development of new spores.

The infection by V. necatrix can have significant impacts on the host, often resulting in the death of the caterpillar. This species has been studied as a potential biological control agent against the gypsy moth, as the infection can reduce the population of this destructive forest pest.

Vairimorpha necatrix is an important model organism for the study of microsporidian biology, host-parasite interactions, and the potential applications of these unique microorganisms in the field of biological control and pest management.
